profileText: A Delegate, a Senator, and a Representative from New Hampshire; born in Amesbury, Mass., May 14, 1739; graduated from Harvard College in 1759; studied theology and was ordained a minister of the Congregational Church in 1763, holding a pastorate in Hampton Falls, N.H., until 1776; moved to Stratham, N.H., in 1776 and engaged in agricultural pursuits; member of the State constitutional convention in 1781; member, State house of representatives 1783; Member of the Continental Congress in 1788; elected to the United States Senate and served from March 4, 1789, to March 3, 1793; elected to the Third Congress (March 4, 1793-March 3, 1795); member, State house of representatives 1795; judge of the superior court of New Hampshire 1798-1809; withdrew from political life and resumed agricultural pursuits; died in Stratham, N.H., on March 7, 1838, being the last survivor of the Continental Congress; interment in Stratham Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Wingate, Charles Edgar Lewis. Life and Letters of Paine Wingate, One of the Fathers of the Nation. 2 vols. Winchester, MA: J.D.P. Wingate, 1930.

researchRecord.name: 1 item (February 21, 1791) in the Chamberlain collection of autographs.
1794. 2 letters. Also 3 items (October 16, 1789-February 17, 1791) in George Washington papers.

7 letters (1789-1790) in the Belknap papers; 18 letters (1789-1790) in the Pickering papers; 2 letters (March 25, June 2, 1790) in the Putnam-Jackson-Lowell papers; and 1 item (April 8, 1789) in Miscellaneous papers.
1 item (August 28, 1789) in the Thomas Addis Emmet collection.
1 item (September 17, 1789) in the Dreer collection; 1 item (October 11, 1790) in the Etting collection; 1 letter (April 27, 1789) in the Gratz collection; and 1 item (September 24, 1789).
1 item (March 14, 1790) in the Charles Roberts autograph collection.

185 items (1 volume) in Hampton Falls, NH, marriage permits, 1742-1776, from his career as a minister; 103 items in Wingate family papers, 1769-1897, including letters received while minister, family letters, a letter from Pierse Long concerning the ratification of Constitution, a letter by Wingate on defeat of General St. Clair, and land deeds; and 1 item (February 4, 1791) in Peabody papers.
1790-1792. 40 letters. Also Wingate's death is discussed extensively in David Joseph Clark diary, January 1, 1838-March 1, 1839.

1732-1850. 3 boxes. Correspondence, family letters, sermons, prayers and forms of service, legal and financial documents, minutes of town and church meetings, diary pages (1764), property records and drawings, indentures, and other papers. Finding aid. Also 1 item (August 1, 1789) in Dearborn collection.
2 letters (1789) in the Timothy Pickering papers; and 1 item (July 18, 1789) in Dr. Henry Wheatland manuscripts.
1 item (September 1, 1789) in Hull collection of letters concerning the Adams family.
